Nov 9 (Reuters) - India's content-to-commerce conglomerate The Good Glamm Group said on Tuesday it had achieved the coveted "unicorn" status, after raising $150 million in its latest funding round co-led by Warburg Pincus and Naspers.

The Good Glamm Group is now valued at $1.2 billion, people familiar with the matter said.

The company's Series D round also saw participation from Alteria Capital and existing investors L'Occitane, Bessemer Venture Partners, Amazon AMZN.O and the Mankekar Family Office. Accel, Trifecta Leaders Fund and Bollywood actress Shraddha Kapoor had also earlier invested in the company.

"With Prosus Ventures (Naspers) and Warburg Pincus as our investors and partners we are perfectly positioned to scale even faster," co-founder Priyanka Gill said.

The Mumbai-based company, which owns beauty products retailer MyGlamm, joins India's growing ranks of unicorns, a name given to startups valued at $1 billion or more. High-profile domestic startups in India include fintech giant CRED and education platform Byju's.

Indian startups have been on a tear in 2021, with several companies entering the unicorn or $1 billion club, while other big names including food delivery app Zomato ZOMT.NS and fintech firm Paytm listing or pursuing a debut on domestic stock exchanges.

The Good Glamm says it provides the brands under its umbrella access to a large digital customer base, and an opportunity to scale offline through more than 30,000 retail points of sale.

The company expects to go public by 2024, and has a current revenue run rate of $120 million. The Good Glamm Group has been on a buying spree this year, adding media platform ScoopWhoop and personal care products retailer MomsCo to its portfolio last month.


(Reporting by Karina Dsouza in Bengaluru; Editing by Krishna Chandra Eluri)
